TITLE.P: PO 8180, Forest Governance, Markets and Climate (FGMC) programme

SHORT_DESCR.P: The Forest Governance, Markets, and Climate (FGMC) programme aims at governance and market reforms that reduce the illegal use of forest resources and benefit poor people who depend on forests for their livelihoods.
It supports global efforts to tackle deforestation, in particular by tackling illegal logging in developing timber-producing countries and the trade in illegally-produced timber products.
It applies lessons from the timber trade to other commodities that impact forests and people who depend on forests for their livelihoods.
It is part of a coordinated endeavor with the EU and is aligned with global efforts involving Norway, China, Japan, the USA, and developing forest countries in Africa, Asia, and Latin America.

FGMC is a 10-year programme (2011-2021) with this requirement running from 2018-2021 and focussing on completing reforms, consolidating gains, and communicating lessons to drive change at both national and international levels.

MAIN_SITE.P: Services may be delivered in Liberia, Ghana, Guyana, Democratic Republic of Congo, Gabon, China, Myanmar, Indonesia, and one other country in either Africa or East Asia..

SHORT_DESCR.P: The intended procurement route is still to be determined and will be discussed further at the Early Market Engagement (EME) event. A DFID Standard Services contract(s) will be awarded.

DFID intends to hold an Early Market Engagement (EME) event on Friday the 2nd February 2018 at 13:30 at DFID's Headquarters at 22 Whitehall, London SW1A 2EG. There will be a facility to dial in remotely to this event.
During the EME representatives from DFID will:
1) Present further details on the requirements,
2) Provide an update on the procurement process, and,
3) Provide an opportunity for attendees to ask questions and contribute to the planned procurement approach.
In addition, there will be an opportunity during the event for networking. An attendance list will be circulated after the event.

In order to register your attendance, you must register your interest on the DFID Supplier Portal (https://supplierportal.dfid.gov.uk/selfservice/) and complete the details requested in the Survey Monkey link that will be available on the DFID Supplier Portal. Due to limited capacity, attendance is restricted to 2 representatives per organization. Places will be reserved on a first come first served basis and when capacity is reached the Survey Monkey will be closed and no further registration will be accepted. You must register by 12:00 (Noon- BST) on Wednesday the 31st January 2018. Please note that only Companies that pre-register will have security clearance to attend the event.

The ‘Dialogue/ Clarification’ function on the DFID Supplier Portal will be the main communication channel moving forward. We are happy to receive questions, comments, and suggestions in advance, which we will respond to at the event, and we will not disclose the source of these when responding.

INFO_ADD.P: This PIN Notice and EME cover the full DFID Forest Governance, Market, and Climate (FGMC) Programme and will provide information on the 6 individual requirements which will be operational as soon as feasible and will run through until 2021. The start and end points for specific contracts will vary depending on the scope of work and timing of when detailed TORs and specifications can be provided.
Suppliers will be sought to deliver the following services:

1) Provision of a team of experts to support the management and monitoring of FGMC. A supplier will provide technical expertise to assist DFID in monitoring the programme, especially projects in the 6 focal countries, and manage approximately 20 accountable grants (with likely value of £40m). A contract value of up to £2.5 million, to be deployed as soon as possible, and by September if feasible.
NOTE: The existing contract is under review and may be extended. Should this happen DFID will not look to contract a new supplier to support the management of FGMC.

2) Facilitation of multi-stakeholder processes in up to 6 countries (including Guyana, Liberia, Ghana and the Republic of Congo). The supplier will deploy experts to be based in each country and to work with national stakeholders across government, the private sector and civil society to support stakeholder-driven dynamic policy, legal and VPA reform processes. 3 years contract, up to £6 million to be deployed as soon as possible, and by September 2018 if feasible.

3) Support to build capacity and create demand for governance reforms as framed by the Liberia VPA. The supplier will build technical capacity of Liberian stakeholders (notably from the private sector, communities, and CSOs) to comply with laws and regulations governing forest production. It will support negotiations between national stakeholders to establish norms and regulations for the informal sector that mainly supplies the domestic market, thereby reducing levels of illegal logging. Up to £6m over 3 years, starting in September 2018.

4) Support to further the UK-China partnership that seeks to tackle illegal logging, to develop sustainable business standards and foster dialogue and responsible investments in developing countries. The focus in developing countries will be to work jointly in Guyana, Myanmar, Gabon, Rep of Congo (country selection still to be determined). Up to £2m over 3 years, starting in January 2019.

5) Technical assistance and support to stakeholders in Guyana to implement the VPA and the legal and governance reforms and system upgrades required to ensure full legal compliance and to meet international market expectations. Detailed TORs will only be developed once the VPA negotiations are concluded (in January 2018) identifying capacity development needs. Up to £3m over 2 years starting in January 2019 if feasible.

6) Independent research to understand the results and impacts of the FGMC programme. Details of the monitoring required will be framed on an annual basis to generate independent information on the influence and results of the programme. A team of experts with governance, economics and forest expertise would be required with detailed knowledge of political economy of the sector in West and Central Africa, the Mekong and Indonesia. It may include final evaluation. Up to £1 million over 2 years, to start by December 2018.
